guest:
The midnight crunch of my cereal was a symphony of solace, until my living room wall *imploded*. Not shattered, but peeled inward like a wet fruit, revealing three towering forms. They were sleek, metallic, with glowing red ocular slits that fixed on my bowl. A guttural, resonant voice echoed, vibrating through my bones. "Terran subject 3-epsilon-7! Your incessant, micro-tremor-inducing mastication has been designated a Level 7 planetary disturbance! Our deep-space probes detect catastrophic resonant frequencies!"

A blinding blue beam shot from the lead alien’s arm, obliterating my cereal bowl, the milk still suspended in the air for a terrifying second before vanishing. Another beam hit my mouth. My jaw locked. I tried to scream, but only a silent gasp escaped.

"Consider your oral cavity recalibrated," the voice boomed. "No longer will your primitive consumption habits threaten the delicate vibrational harmonies of local spacetime. Enjoy your... liquid sustenance." They phased out, leaving the wall perfectly restored. I tried to open my mouth. My jaw remained sealed. The only way to eat now was through a straw.

I was mid-dream, chasing a sentient cheese wheel through a jungle of oversized teacups, when my bedroom wall shimmered. Three tall, slender figures, made of shifting starlight, phased through. Their multi-faceted eyes, like tiny galaxies, focused on me. A voice, a chorus of whispering winds, filled my head. "Terran Unit 7-Omega-9! Your nocturnal cerebral projections are a breach! Your unregulated dream-weaving is distorting our dimensional pathways!"

I blinked, still half in the cheese-wheel jungle. "My dreams? What about them?"

A glowing tendril extended from the lead alien, touching my forehead. A jolt, not painful, but disorienting. My dreamscape, previously a vibrant kaleidoscope, suddenly felt… muted. Grey. Flat. The aliens hummed with satisfaction.

"We have harmonized your synaptic activity," the whispers declared. "No longer will your chaotic fantasies threaten interstellar stability. Enjoy your... tranquil slumber." They vanished. I closed my eyes, trying to conjure the cheese wheel. All I saw was a barren, grey plain. But then, a flicker. A small, vibrant daisy sprouted. Then another. Soon, the grey plain was covered in a field of impossible, neon flowers, each one humming a different, delightful tune. My dreams weren't gone; they were just… *redesigned*, into a fantastical, silent symphony for one.

Yash was watching the city lights blur into the twilight, a mug of cold tea clutched in hand. A quiet evening, exactly what he craved after a week of relentless deadlines. Then, the sky above the skyline *tore open*. Not with a sound, but a silent, violet rip, widening to reveal a dizzying expanse of swirling nebulae and obsidian structures that pulsed with an unseen power. Panic clawed at Yash’s throat as the streetlights below flickered out, one by one, like dying embers.

A beam of iridescent light, thicker than any skyscraper, descended. It wasn’t aimed at the city, but directly at Yash’s apartment. He braced himself for impact, for annihilation. But the light didn't destroy; it *unwound*. The walls dissolved into shimmering motes, the floor evaporated beneath his feet. Fear turned to a chilling wonder as his own body began to unravel, not painfully, but like threads of starlight coming undone.

A resonant hum filled the void. "Subject Alpha-7," a voice echoed, not through his ears, but his very being. "Recall initiated. Your long-term data acquisition cycle is complete. Time to return to true form." Yash felt his consciousness expand, his human shell finally shed, revealing a form composed of pure energy, ready to merge with the stellar void. The "attack" was merely an awakening.

Yash was precisely 38 minutes into his favourite reality show, "Galactic Bake-Off: Quantum Edition," when his living room wall shimmered. Three tall, bulbous creatures, resembling disgruntled space-cucumbers, phased through, their multiple eyes narrowed to angry slits.

"Terran Unit 7-Omega-9!" the lead cucumber-alien boomed, its voice a symphony of static and offended squeaks that echoed in Yash’s skull. "You are in gross violation of the Interstellar Noise Ordinance! Cease your chaotic sonic emissions immediately!"

Yash, startled, dropped his remote, narrowly missing his cat, Mittens. "My... my TV? Is the volume too high? I can turn it down."

The cucumber-alien quivered with indignation. "Volume is irrelevant! Your incessant broadcasting of 'Galactic Bake-Off' has infiltrated our quadrant! Our Supreme Leader has developed an inexplicable fascination with soufflés and is now demanding we replace all planetary defence systems with industrial-grade mixers!" It pointed a tentacle at Yash’s battered, decades-old universal remote. "That device! It radiates pure, unadulterated competitive-baking energy!"

Yash blinked, picking up the remote. "This old thing? It barely turns on." He accidentally pressed a button. Suddenly, the cucumbers gasped, pointing accusingly at each other. "You used my star-flour!" one shrieked. "My recipe was clearly superior!" another retorted. Yash sighed, muted the TV, and went to make a cup of tea. He knew from experience, intergalactic baking arguments lasted *ages*.

Akshat shivered, not from the biting desert wind, but the grim task ahead. Six high-value targets, code-named 'The Scourge,' were holed up in a reinforced desert compound. Their broadcasts were poisoning regional stability, their influence spreading like a disease. Conventional assault meant civilian casualties; Akshat preferred a cleaner approach. He activated his gauntlet, the humming increasing to a low thrum. "Time to cook," he whispered, the words holding a chilling, technical precision.

A wave of invisible energy washed over the compound. Inside, the terrorists dropped their weapons, confused. Their skin prickled, then began to glow faintly. Their muscles seized, then relaxed. Akshat watched through his thermal scope as their forms shimmered, becoming less defined, like sand castles dissolving in a tide. No blood, no screams. Just a silent, controlled unraveling.

When the last signature vanished, Akshat walked in. The compound was empty, save for a thin, iridescent mist that hung in the air. He activated a portable containment unit, drawing the mist inside. This was the "bad energy" he sought, neatly extracted. His mission wasn't to kill, but to purify; the nebulous residue, once refined, would fuel the next interstellar peace initiative.
